text:
Blob Detection
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blob

A blob in computer vision is a region of image that some
properties is constant or approximately constant
Example of properties:
Color
Brightness

A robot can detect an object with a solid color by simply find
blobs of that color
A blob usually defined as a rectangular region with information:
Width and Height
Number of pixels
Coordinate of the center of the region

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 How to Detect a Blob?
Consider the following image:

How to detect a red ball in the above image?
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Filter Selected Color

Image generally comes in RGB format
Each pixel is represented by three values, red, green, and blue
To filter out a specific color, we simply define ranges for each
value
Red between 120 to 130,
Green between 78 to 90, and
Blue between 100 to 110

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 How to Detect a Blob
Filter out every color but red

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 How to Detect a Blob
Detect connected regions

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Filter Selected Color

Note that an object generally stays in a foreground where
environment is in the background
Foreground objects generally have more brightness
In computer vision, we prefer YUV format:
Y stands for the luminance component (the brightness)
U and V are the chrominance (color) components

Conversion between RGB and YUV is straightforward:
𝑌 = (0.299 × 𝑅) + (0.587 × 𝐺) + (0.114 × 𝐵)
𝑈 = (−0.168736 × 𝑅) + (−0.331264 × 𝐺) + (0.5 × 𝐵)
𝑉 = (0.5 × 𝑅) + (−0.418688 × 𝐺) + (−0.081312 × 𝐵)

where 𝑅, 𝐺, and 𝐵 have values between 0.0 and 1.0

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Problems with Blob Detection
If we have two objects with the same color, at least two blobs
will be detected
If we have only one object, more than one blobs may be detected
Lighting effects color
Filtered regions may not connect with each other
Two or more blobs but on the same object
If all blobs come from the same object, they will be close to each
other

Surrounding environment may have the same color

Same object may not be detected if lighting change
Increase the range of color may result in detecting environment
instead of desire object
Only works in restricted lighting and surrounding environment
has small number of colors

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Applications

Object Recognition and Tracking:
Soccer: Ball and goal posts
Navigation: Follows a line
Object avoidance

Robot Location/Orientation:
Two colors on top of robot
Signs (multi-colors) represent locations

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Integrated Web Camera
To detect blobs, we need an image or a series of images
We will use integrated Web camera of your given laptop
To access the web cam, we need another node called gscam
gscam node communicate with integrated Web cam
Capture video and turn them into series of images
Each image will be published on the topic
/v4l/camera/image_raw

To start gscam node, use the following command:
roslaunch gscam v4l.launch

A series of images can be viewed using image_view node as
follows:
rosrun image_view image_view image:=/v4l/camera/image_raw

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Image Message
Images published by gscam node has type
sensor_msg/Image.msgs
If you want to access images, add the following:
from sensor_msg.msgs import Image

The Image message consists of the following components:
header: Information about message
height: Image height (number of rows)
width: Image width (number of columns)
encoding: Type of encoding
is_bigendian: Is this data bigendian
step: How many bytes in a row
data: A one-dimensional array of data. The number of elements
is step * rows ([B,G,R,B,G,R,...])

Lucky us, we do not have to process images directly.

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 View Image from Camera using OpenCV
We can create our own image viewer from camera using OpenCV
First, we need to convert a color image message into OpenCV
format
Then, simply display the image
Code Example:
#!/usr/bin/env python
import rospy
import cv2
from sensor_msgs.msg import Image
from cv_bridge import CvBridge, CvBridgeError
colorImage = None
isColorImageReady = False
def updateColorImage(data):
global colorImage, isColorImageReady
colorImage = data
isColorImageReady = True

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 View Image from Camera using OpenCV
Code Example (continue):
def main():
global colorImage, isColorImageReady
rospy.init_node('myimageview', anonymous=True)
rospy.Subscriber('/v4l/camera/image_raw', Image, updateColorImage)
bridge = CvBridge()
cv2.namedWindow('Image from Camera')
while not rospy.is_shutdown() and not isColorImageReady:
pass
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
try:
color_image = bridge.imgmsg_to_cv2(colorImage, "bgr8")
except CvBridgeError, e:
print e
cv2.imshow('Image from Camera', color_image)
key = cv2.waitKey(1)
if key == ord('q'):
break
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 cmvision Node

cmvision node detects blobs of colors from Image message
Subscribes to a topic (of type Image) of your choice
In our case, the topic will be:
/v4l/camera/image_raw

Obtains user defined color information about blobs to be detected
Publishes information about detect blobs on the topic /blobs

cmvision package also supplies a tool named colorgui
Allows user to pick a range of colors of an object of interest
Shows visual image of detect blobs associated with picked color
Supplies color information and threshold

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colorgui

Before running colorgui node, make sure your roscore and
gscam is running
To run colorgui, use the following command:
rosrun cmvision colorgui image:=/v4l/camera/image_raw

Note that the data in topic /v4l/camera/image_raw is
published by gscam node
A windows will pop-up and shows the image from your camera

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colorgui

After clicking on the object in the image couple times, you may
see a set of rectangles
Each rectangle represents a detected blob
Move object around to see whether it can detect the object
If it cannot detect, click on the object couple more times to
increase the range of detecting color
Information at the bottom (YUV) will be use to set the color to
be detected

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colorgui Example
First couple clicks

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colorgui Example
Couple more clicks around the desired object

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colorgui Example
Couple more and take note about RGB and YUV

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colors.txt
For cmvision node, color information should be stored in a
text file
By default, the name of the text file is colors.txt
A color file consists of two parts [colors] and
[thresholds] as shown below:
[colors]
(150, 166, 83) 0.000000 1 BrightGreen
[thresholds]
(151:163, 85:91, 121:126)

cmvision node can be used to detect more than one color by
adding more lines for [colors] and [thresholds]
[colors]
(150, 166, 83) 0.000000 1 BrightGreen
(0, 255, 0) 0.000000 2 Green
[thresholds]
(151:163, 85:91, 121:126)
(47:87, 148:162, 93:113)
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colors.txt
Consider the following color file:
[colors]
(150, 166, 83) 0.000000 1 BrightGreen
(0, 255, 0) 0.000000 2 Green
[thresholds]
(151:163, 85:91, 121:126)
(47:87, 148:162, 93:113)

Each line under [colors] consists of the following:
(R, G, B): The red, green, and blue values of rectangles that
are used to blob region
0.000000: Not being used any more (I guess)
1: Not being used any more (I guess)
BrightGreen: The name of the blob which can be used to
distinguish among multiple detected blobs

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 colors.txt

Consider the following color file:
[colors]
(150, 166, 83) 0.000000 1 BrightGreen
(0, 255, 0) 0.000000 2 Green
[thresholds]
(151:163, 85:91, 121:126)
(47:87, 148:162, 93:113)

Each line under [thresholds] consists of the following:
(minY:maxY, minU:maxU, minV:maxV): The YUV
threshold from colorgui

Note that the first line of colors is associated with the first line
of thresholds, and so on

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 cmvision.launch
Parameters of cmvision are needed to be set
First, copy the default launch file:
/home/student/cs1567/src/cmvision/cmvision.launch

to your ../mypackage directory
In the copied file, change the followings:
Under param name="cmvision/color_file", change
its value to
value="/home/student/cs1567/src/mypackage/colors.txt"

If you put colors.txt in different directory, adjust it
accordingly
Under param name="cmvision/debug_on", change the
value to
value="true" if you want to see image and detect blobs while
cmvision is running
value="false" otherwise

Under node name="cmvision" change the args to
args="image:=/v4l/camera/image_raw"
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 cmvision.launch
Your cmvision.launch should look like the following:
<launch>
<!-- Location of the cmvision color file -->
<param name="cmvision/color_file" type="string"
value="/home/student/cs1567/src/mypackage/colors.txt" />
<!-- Turn debug output on or off -->
<param name="cmvision/debug_on" type="bool" value="true"/>
<!-- Turn color calibration on or off -->
<param name="cmvision/color_cal_on" type="bool" value="false"/>
<!-- Enable Mean shift filtering -->
<param name="cmvision/mean_shift_on" type="bool" value="false"/>
<!-- Spatial bandwidth: Bigger = smoother image -->
<param name="cmvision/spatial_radius_pix" type="double" value="2.0"/>
<!-- Color bandwidth: Bigger = smoother image-->
<param name="cmvision/color_radius_pix" type="double" value="40.0"/>
<node name="cmvision" pkg="cmvision" type="cmvision" args="image:=/v4l/camera/image_raw"
output="screen" />
</launch>

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blobs.msgs

cmvision node publishes a message of type Blobs
Again, import it first:
from cmvision.msg import Blobs

A message of type Blobs consists of various components:
header: Message header
image_width: The width of the image in pixels
image_height: The height of the image in pixels
blob_count: The number of detected blobs
blobs: An array of data of type Blob

Note: Blob (with out s) is another type of message

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blob.msgs
Blob.msgs stores information about each blob detected by
cmvision node
Must be explicitly imported:
from cmvision.msg import Blobs, Blob

A message of type Blob consists of various components:
name: The name of color/object specified in colors.txt
(String)
red: The value of red
green: The value of green
blue: The value of blue
area: The area of the blob (number of pixels)
x: The x coordinate of the center of the blob
y: The y coordinate of the center of the blob
left: The x coordinate of the left side of the region
right: The x coordinate of the right side of the region
top: The y coordinate of the top side of the region
bottom: The y coordinate of the bottom side of the region
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blob.msgs
(0,0)

left

right

top

(x,y)

bottom

blob

image

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Problem Solving Ideas

How to filter out environment?
How do we know that two or more blobs are on the same object?
Fixed size objects
Variable size objects

If we know that these 10 blobs are on the same object, how to
find the center of the object?
How do we know that there are two or more objects of the same
color?
How to filter out noise from camera?

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Visualize Blobs using OpenCV

Sometimes we need to process blobs:
Filter out blobs that are too smalls
Filter out blobs that are outside of region of interest
Merge multiple blobs in to one

We may need to see a result in an image
OpenCV provides libraries for Computer Vision:
Show image/video on screen
Mouse and keyboard events
Draw lines, rectangles, string on image
Foreground/background filtering

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Visualize Blobs using OpenCV
#!/usr/bin/env python
import roslib
import rospy
import cv2
import copy
from sensor_msgs.msg import Image
from cv_bridge import CvBridge, CvBridgeError
from cmvision.msg import Blobs, Blob
colorImage = Image()
isColorImageReady = False
blobsInfo = Blobs()
isBlobsInfoReady = False
def updateColorImage(data):
global colorImage, isColorImageReady
colorImage = data
isColorImageReady = True
def updateBlobsInfo(data):
global blobsInfo, isBlobsInfoReady
blobsInfo = data
isBlobsInfoReady = True
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Visualize Blobs using OpenCV

def main():
global colorImage, isColorImageReady, blobsInfo, isBlobsInfoReady
rospy.init_node('showBlobs', anonymous=True)
rospy.Subscriber("/blobs", Blobs, updateBlobsInfo)
rospy.Subscriber("/v4l/camera/image_raw", Image, updateColorImage)
bridge = CvBridge()
cv2.namedWindow("Blob Location")
while not rospy.is_shutdown() and
(not isBlobsInfoReady or not isColorImageReady):
pass
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
:

 Visualize Blobs using OpenCV
def main():
:
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
try:
color_image = bridge.imgmsg_to_cv2(colorImage, "bgr8")
except CvBridgeError, e:
print e
print "colorImage"
blobsCopy = copy.deepcopy(blobsInfo)
for b in blobsCopy.blobs:
cv2.rectangle(color_image, (b.left, b.top),
(b.right, b.bottom), (0,255,0), 2)
cv2.imshow("Color Image", color_image)
key = cv2.waitKey(1)
if key == ord('q'):
break
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blob Detection Algorithm

Given an image, the following steps are generally used:
1
2
3

Blur the image to reduce noise
Filter out all pixels that are out-of-range
Find groups of pixels that are connected to each other

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Gaussian Blur

One of the most popular blur algorithm is called Gaussian blur

3x3
5x5
7x7

The new RGB values of the pixel at center is an weight average
of RGB of pixels around it
The weight of each pixel is based on the Gaussian normal
distribution

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Filter
Filter can be done based on RGB or YUV
Recall that cmvision uses YUV

Once a filter is applied, we should get a one bit image (black and
white)
We do not need information about color of each pixel anymore
Only need to know which pixels are in a given range

Example:

1

Record this coordinate so that we can restart searching for the
next blob
Construct a new blob (data)
Left and right are 5
Top and bottom are 1
Center, width, and height of the blob will be calculated later

Now, our first blob is (5, 5, 1, 1)

 A Blob Detection Algorithm
Next, set the pixel to zero and scanning for non-zero neighbor
If a non-zero neighbor is found:
Adjust the blob accordingly
Add coordinate (x,y) of the non-zero neighbor into a queue
Change non-zero neighbors to 0

 A Blob Detection Algorithm
Repeat until the queue is empty:
1
2
3
4
5

Dequeue the first coordinate
Scan for its non-zero neighbor
Add all coordinates (x,y) of the non-zero neighbor into a queue
Change all non-zero neighbor to 0
Go back to step 1

Once the queue is empty, we get the first blob (5, 7, 1, 7)

 Blob Detection using OpenCV
First, we need to blur an image using the GaussianBlur()
function
The following code blurs an image and display:
import cv2
def main():
color_image = cv2.imread('start_img.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
blur_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(color_image, (5, 5), 0)
cv2.imshow('Image', color_image)
cv2.imshow('Blur Image', blur_image)
while True:
key = cv2.waitKey(0) & 0xFF
if key == ord('q'):
break;
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

The parameter (5, 5) specifies how many pixels to be used
(must be odd numbers)
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Convert RGB to YUV
OpenCV supplies the cvtColor() function to convert one
color spectrum to another
import cv2
def main():
color_image = cv2.imread('../start_img.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
blur_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(color_image, (5, 5), 0)
yuv_image = cv2.cvtColor(blur_image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2YUV)
y, u, v = cv2.split(yuv_image)
cv2.imshow('Image', blur_image)
cv2.imshow('Y', y)
cv2.imshow('U', u)
cv2.imshow('V', v)
while True:
key = cv2.waitKey(0) & 0xFF
if key == ord('q'):
break;
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Filter Unwanted Pixels

Unwanted pixels can be filtered out using the inRange()
function:
def main():
color_image = cv2.imread('../start_img.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
blur_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(color_image, (5, 5), 0)
cv2.namedWindow('Mask')
mask_image = cv2.inRange(blur_image, lower_bound, upper_bound);
cv2.imshow('Mask', mask_image)
cv2.waitkey(0);
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

The lower_bound and upper_bound are (B, G, R) in
this case

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Filter Unwanted Pixels
Masked Image:

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 SimpleBlobDetector()

OpenCV supplies the SimpleBlobDetector() function
which detects blobs based on a given parameter:

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 SimpleBlobDetector() Parameters
First we need to set the parameter:
params = cv2.SimpleBlobDetector_Params()
params.minThreshold = 0
params.maxThreshold = 255
params.filterByArea = True
params.minArea = 50
params.maxArea = 256 * 256
params.filterByCircularity = False
params.minCircularity = 0.1
params.filterByConvexity = False
params.minConvexity = 0.9
params.filterByInertia = False
params.minInertiaRatio = 0.5
ver = (cv2.__version__).split('.')
if int(ver[0]) < 3:
detector = cv2.SimpleBlobDetector(params)
else:
detector = cv2.SimpleBlobDetector_create(params)

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 SimpleBlobDetector()

Then we can use the detector object to detect blobs from
masked image
keypoints = detector.detect(255 - mask_image)
kp_image =
cv2.drawKeypoints(blur_image,
keypoints,
np.array([]),
(0, 255, 0),
cv2.DRAW_MATCHES_FLAGS_DRAW_RICH_KEYPOINTS)
cv2.imshow('Keypoints', kp_image)

To extract blobs information, simply look at the keypoints
variable

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 SimpleBlobDetector()
Result from the drawKeypoints() function to the original
image:

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 SimpleBlobDetector()

The SimpleBlobDetector() function is good for round
object
It may not perform well for our application (high CPU utilization)
With a large blob, it only show a small keypoint
Parameters are hard to understand

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 Blob Detection using Contour

Another method is to detect contours of masked image
A contour is a curve joining all the continuous points (along the
boundary), having same color or intensity
The contours are a useful tool for shape analysis and object
detection and recognition
In OpenCV, the function findContours() is given

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 findContours()

findContours() example:
def main():
color_image = cv2.imread('../start_img.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
blur_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(color_image, (5, 5), 0)
cv2.namedWindow('Contour Image')
(cnts, _) = cv2.findContours(mask_image.copy(), cv2.RETR_TREE,
cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
cv2.drawContours(blur_image, cnts, -1, (0,255,0), 3)
cv2.imshow('Contour Image', blur_image)
cv2.waitKey(0);
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 drawContours()
Use the drawContours() to draw all contours into the
original image

Note that there are contours inside other contours
We need bounding box for each contour and eliminate contours
that are inside another
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 findContours() with hierarchy
Filter out some contours
def main():
color_image = cv2.imread('../start_img.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
blur_image = cv2.GaussianBlur(color_image, (5, 5), 0)
cv2.namedWindow('Bounding')
(cnts, hierarchy) = cv2.findContours(mask_image.copy(),
cv2.RETR_TREE,
cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
for i in range(0, len(cnts)):
c = cnts[i]
if cv2.contourArea(c) < 100:
continue
if not hierarchy[0][i][3] == -1:
continue
x,y,w,h = cv2.boundingRect(c)
cv2.rectangle(blur_image, (x,y), (x + w, y + h),
(0, 255, 0), 3);
cv2.imshow('Bounding', blur_image)
cv2.waitKey(0);
cv2.destroyAllWindows()
if __name__ == '__main__':
main()

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Blob Detection

 drawContours()
After filtering out small contours and those that are inside another
